sn12.4:1.2: The story of Vipassī is detailed in the Mahāpadāna Sutta, with which this passage is mostly shared (DN 14:2.18.5). In early texts, Vipassī is always mentioned with the full group of seven Buddhas (Thag 7.5, DN 32:3.2, Bu Pj 1:3.1.6). | Bodhisatta is explained by the commentary here as either “one possessed of awakening”, or one who is certain of awakening in the proximity of Buddhahood. The latter explanation allows a reading equivalent to Sanskrit bodhiśakta (“one intent on awakening”), rather than the more familiar bodhisattva (“awakening-being”).
sn12.4:2.2: This phrasing corresponds to the abstract principle of dependent origination (SN 12.37:2.2). Compare Śaunaka’s question at Muṇḍaka Upoaniṣad 1.2.3:  “When what is understood, sir, is all this understood?” (kasmin nu bhagavo vijñāte sarvaṁ idaṁ vijñātaṁ bhavati).
sn12.4:2.3: Yoniso maniskāra (“rational application of mind”) is a distinctively Buddhist term that literally means “applying the mind by way of source”. It is mostly used in investigating causality, although over time it came to have a more general sense of “reflection, inquiry, attention”.
sn12.4:11.4: Here we have the normal twelve links, whereas in DN 14 the sequence omits ignorance and choices, emphasizing rather the mutual interdependence of consciousness with name and form, a variation found also in the context of Gotama’s awakening at SN 12.65.
sn12.4:25.4: This phrasing recalls the Buddha’s first sermon (SN 56.11:5.1), an insight that is said to be common to all Buddhas (SN 56.12:1.1). | Pubbe ananussutesu (“not learned before from another”) means that this is a fresh insight not passed down in an oral tradition.
sn12.4:26.1: This instruction is noted in the Pali text.
